summary: A Finance department user received a phishing email with a macro-enabled Word document. The user opened the attachment, which triggered PowerShell to execute an encoded command attempting to download a payload from a known malicious C2 server associated with FIN7.
risk_reasoning: High risk due to: (1) Confirmed execution chain from email attachment to PowerShell, (2) C2 domain matches known FIN7 infrastructure with 78% confidence, (3) Target user is in Finance with access to sensitive financial data, (4) Asset criticality is high. This appears to be an active compromise requiring immediate containment.
key_findings: Macro-enabled document (Q4_Report.docm) opened by user triggered PowerShell execution
PowerShell attempted to download payload from known FIN7 C2 infrastructure
User is in Finance department with potential access to sensitive financial systems
No prior alerts for this user - this is first suspicious activity
Workstation was recently patched (2025-01-15) but Office macros were not blocked
investigation_steps: Immediately isolate workstation WS-JD-001 via Defender for Endpoint to prevent lateral movement
Check if PowerShell download succeeded - query DeviceNetworkEvents for connections to 203.0.113.50
Review DeviceProcessEvents for any child processes spawned by the PowerShell command
Search for the email across all mailboxes and purge any unread instances
Contact user john.doe@company.com to confirm they did not expect this document and gather additional context

suggested_queries.kql:
// Check for successful C2 connection and follow-on activity
DeviceNetworkEvents
| where TimeGenerated > ago(4h)
| where DeviceName == "WS-JD-001"
| where RemoteIP == "203.0.113.50" or RemoteUrl contains "malicious-c2.com"
| project TimeGenerated, ActionType, RemoteIP, RemotePort, RemoteUrl, InitiatingProcessFileName
| order by TimeGenerated asc
suggested_queries.spl:
index=endpoint host="WS-JD-001" earliest=-4h
| search (dest_ip="203.0.113.50" OR dest_host="*malicious-c2.com*")
| table _time, action, dest_ip, dest_port, dest_host, process_name
| sort _time

mitre_context: This attack chain maps to: T1566.001 (Spearphishing Attachment) → T1059.001 (PowerShell) → T1105 (Ingress Tool Transfer). This is a classic FIN7 initial access technique targeting financial sector employees with macro-enabled documents.
suggested_actions: Disable user account john.doe@company.com pending investigation
Block sender domain suspicious-domain.com at email gateway
Add C2 domain malicious-c2.com and IP 203.0.113.50 to firewall block list
Purge email from all mailboxes organization-wide
Notify Finance BISO of potential compromise in their department
escalation_reason: Risk score 9/10 with confirmed execution and FIN7 attribution. Finance user with potential access to sensitive data. Requires immediate L2/L3 engagement and potential incident declaration.
